title: 110_s1894
content: The Act titled "Support for Injured Servicemembers Act of 2007" includes provisions for Servicemember Family Leave. The "Support for Injured Servicemembers Act of 2007" defines combat-related injury and servicemember, and provides entitlement to servicemember family leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act. The "Support for Injured Servicemembers Act of 2007" allows eligible employees to take up to 26 workweeks of leave to care for a servicemember with a combat-related injury. This leave can be taken intermittently or on a reduced schedule. The "Support for Injured Servicemembers Act of 2007" allows eligible employees to take up to 26 workweeks of leave to care for a servicemember with a combat-related injury. This leave can be substituted with paid leave under subsection (a)(3). The employer may require the employee to substitute accrued paid vacation, personal, family, or medical leave for servicemember family leave. Notice and certification requirements are also outlined for servicemember family leave under the "Support for Injured Servicemembers Act of 2007." The employer may require certification for leave under section 102(a)(3) as outlined in the "Support for Injured Servicemembers Act of 2007." Failure to return may result in a certification issued by the health care provider of the primary caregiver. The Family and Medical Leave Act is amended to allow up to 26 weeks of leave for employees unable to return to work due to a specified condition. Enforcement and instructional employee provisions are also updated. SEC. 3. SERVICEMEMBER FAMILY LEAVE FOR CIVIL SERVICE EMPLOYEES. Definitions in Section 6381 of title 5, United States Code are amended to include the term 'combat-related injury' and 'servicemember'. Combat-related injury is defined as an injury incurred during armed conflict, hazardous service, duty simulating war, or through an instrumentality of war. Servicemember refers to a member of the Armed Forces. The amendment allows an employee to take 26 weeks of leave to care for a servicemember with a combat-related injury. Leave can be taken intermittently or on a reduced schedule. The amendment allows an employee to substitute paid leave for caring for a servicemember with a combat-related injury. Notice and certification requirements are also specified. The amendment allows employees to substitute paid leave for caring for a servicemember with a combat-related injury. An employing agency may require a certification for leave under section 6382(a)(3) as prescribed by the Office of Personnel Management.
